entry.title: Om Malik在苹果情报上：“ FUD，DUD或两者兼而有之”
entry.content:
Om Malik：

我有自己的解释，我的读者熟悉了这一点，这是最明显的。就像Google被困在10个蓝色链路监狱中一样，它阻止了它做激进分子的事情，苹果拥有自己的金色手铐。这是一家公司的市值以及股票市场对此的期望。

他们缺乏史蒂夫·乔布斯（Steve Jobs）的道德权威来无视市场，简化其产品阵容并集中于公司。取而代之的是，他们做一个复杂的业务经常做的事情：他们会做更多的事情。他们可以在iPados做得更好吗？ Vision Pro应该受到更多关注吗？

所有这些的答案是肯定的。苹果已经成为一个复杂的实体，似乎没有足够的资源来提供真正的苹果体验。您得到的是“足够好”。在大多数情况下，我认为这足够了 - 因为市场上的其他人更糟。他们知道如何构建出色的硬件；这是他们步履蹒跚的软件。就苹果智能而言，它们被捕获了很短，因为其他人的AI产品即使有缺陷，也比苹果自己的产品要好得多。

硬件天生可以使公司保持诚实，而软件则不能。硬件要么有效，要么无效。 “升级”硬件的唯一方法是通过安装较新的软件，或将硬件拆开并替换物理组件。在任何领域，都很难想到其软件比硬件“更好”的领域。也许是任天堂？但是，即使有任天堂，我也会说他们的软件和硬件一样好。另外，一个有趣的想法突然出现在我的头上阅读Malik的帖子：使Vision Pro如此有趣的部分原因是该软件比硬件更好。沉浸式VR的硬件是如此初期，以至于即使是在五年内将要处于何处，即使是行业的最先进的愿景，也是象征性的。 1984年的Macintosh是一台肮脏的计算机，带有9英寸的一位显示器，没有硬盘驱动器，并且荒谬的128千摩变ram。但是该软件很棒！

但是，马利克（Malik）提出的更大，更好的观点是，“足够好”足以使苹果的软件在竞争中显得领先。我试图以“苹果需要尼康”的身份在2007年一直提出这一点，我认为现在的问题比那时更糟。没有其他公司在苹果联盟中模糊不清。但是苹果在软件方面朝着平庸的方向滑行。辩论他们滑了多远，这是非常开放的。我会说，他们没有滑倒，诚实的估算 - 尤其是关于与Siri和Ai有关的一切，他们可以在芽中咬住这一点。您可能会争辩说，他们全面滑倒了。但是我认为没有什么可以说的是他们的竞争仍然低于苹果联盟。这就是让库比蒂诺的声音相信一切都很好的原因。苹果是UI设计顶级唯一的团队。

苹果可能发生的最好的事情是Google运送Android像素体验，这实际上使iPhone所有者疯狂地嫉妒。 Google无法通过UI设计这样做。他们无法赶上硬件的苹果。但是也许在AI前部，他们可以做到。苹果需要一个竞争对手。

★

entry.title: 特斯拉的股价从来就一直在怀疑
entry.content:
特斯拉的股价最近一直很困难。自从12月以来，该股票的价值损失了大约一半的价值，自从马斯克（Musk）与唐纳德·特朗普（Donald Trump）一起上任以来， 连续7周跌落，上周只有如此大的篮板，在马斯克（Musk）让美国总统将白宫草坪变成奶酪的特斯拉（Tesla）（遗憾的是，特斯勒（Tesler ）经销商）之后。在整个市场略有上涨的一天，特斯拉股票今天又下降了5％。

我在1月31日在《金融时报》上为这家布莱斯长老专栏添加了书签，现在似乎是链接到它的好时机：

当特斯拉交易类似于泵的时候，通常的解释是：“因为埃隆说话很多”。这是摩根大通分析师瑞安·布林克曼（Ryan Brinkman），以扩大主题：

我们尚不清楚为什么特斯拉在周三的售后市场上股票高达5％，尽管我们有一些领先的理论。也许是管理层的声明，它已经确定了一条可实现的途径，比全球五家最有价值的公司在一起的途径（即，超过14.8万亿美元的苹果，微软，Nvidia，Amazon和Alphabet的14.8万亿美元的市值）。也许管理层的信念是，只有一种产品本身就有可能产生“ 10万亿美元收入的北部”。它甚至可能与2026年管理指南有关（没有提供财务目标，但据说是“史诗般的”），以及2027年和2028年（“荒谬的好”）。

布林克曼（Brinkman）在特斯拉（Tesla）上拥有长期的“体重不足”评级，他开始听起来有些生气：

公司的财务业绩和彭博社共同获得收入，利润率，收益和现金流的共识都不断下降，但分析师的价格目标和公司的股价不断上涨。例如，特斯拉在过去10个季度中的9个中错过了彭博社共识EBIT，平均为-16.3％。

始终缺少估计是一回事。特斯拉一直在做的事情一直缺少降低的估计。 [...]

特斯拉的最大资产是夸张。夸张越极端，它越有价值。也许下班后市场参与者比特斯拉熊更好地了解动态，因此可以在氛围上停放基本面和贸易。或者，也许其他事情正在发生。

听起来很像白宫自动购物中心的另一个人。

★

entry.title: 射线制造商在Beats PowerBeats的心率传感器上2 Pro
entry.content:
Ray Maker，在DC Rainmaker写作：

这不仅是苹果第一次创建非观察心率传感器，而且更值得注意的是，该公司首次在现有的蓝牙心率标准上启用心率广播。

然后问题变成：它准确吗？

不幸的是，事实证明，这不是我应该开始的问题。首先，真正的问题是：心率功能（准确性）是否可用？很多小时后，我对这两个问题都有答案。相信我，这是一个非常混杂的袋子。

答案：

很明显，任何运动（即使是固定的自行车）都会迅速导致辍学或心率不正确。而且在户外活动，情况更糟。最终，我在该产品中没有任何值得的心率传感器中的任何价值，因为它根本不足以有用，即使对于随意使用也是如此。

因此，也许此功能不久之后会出现在AirPods上？

★

entry.title: Chance Miller评论Beats PowerBeats Pro 2
entry.content:
我是一个月晚些时候链接到它，但是Chance Miller为9to5mac写了一篇了不起的评论：

Beats的最后几个版本，例如Studio Buds Plus和Solo 4耳机，由定制Beats芯片提供动力，而不是像AirPods中使用的苹果设计的芯片一样。对于Beats，这使Android用户提供了更好的跨平台支持，但它也以苹果粉丝的几个流行功能为代价。例如，工作室的芽加上对自动射入检测，iCloud配对，自动设备开关，个性化空间音频等的支持。

有了PowerBeats Pro 2，Beats又回到了它的根源，并选择了苹果设计的芯片。 PowerBeats Pro 2由Apple的H2芯片提供动力，与最新一代AirPods Pro 2和Airpods 4相同的芯片。这意味着您可以获得全套以苹果为中心的音频功能。

苹果团队和Beats之间的共同工程学程度对我来说总是很奇怪。有时，Beats似乎确实是一个独立的子公司，专注于跨平台耳机，而其他时候，就像他们在不同品牌标签下制作苹果产品一样。甜蜜的位置似乎是关于他们使用这些强力游戏2的地方。

上述所有功能和改进使PowerBeats Pro 2成为令人信服的产品，但Beats还有一件事：PowerBeats Pro 2功能内置心率监测。

每个PowerBeats Pro 2耳塞都有一个内置的心率监视器，该监视器由四个组件组成。首先，有一个LED传感器以每秒超过100脉冲的速度排放绿色LED灯。这种光通过皮肤发出，并击中您的红细胞。然后，光电二极管从红细胞中接收到由红色血流调节的红细胞的反射光。有一个光学镜头，有助于指导和分离发射和接收的光，以及加速度计，以确保数据收集的准确性和一致性。

Beats补充说，PowerBeats Pro 2的心率传感器技术来自Apple在Apple Watch上的工作。

在苹果自己的Airpods之前，Beats怪异但很酷。但是现在，这似乎是一个锁，这将是AirPods Pro 3中的功能，对吗？

我在阅读的评论中一直想要的东西 - 以及我试图通过自己的评论提供给读者的内容 - 是对产品是否适合我的感觉。 PowerBeats Pro 2不适合我 - 我知道，因为Miller的评论很好地描述了它们。但是它们似乎是许多人喜欢AirPods Pro的绝妙产品。

★
;

entry.title: 苹果从Mobileme那里学到的苹果（希望没有忘记）的迈克尔·加顿（Michael Gartenberg）
entry.content:
塞巴斯蒂亚·德（Sebastiaan de）上周与我的“东西烂”作品链接在一起：

前Mobileme团队在这里。这是一个残酷的时期。

太糟糕了，当他在舞台上介绍iCloud时，史蒂夫说：“我知道你在想什么：我为什么要信任他们？

迈克尔·加滕伯格（Michael Gartenberg）（在苹果公司在工作时代的尾巴​​末端工作了几年），回答（跨两条推文）：

当我在苹果大学和苹果大学时，仍然有一门关于Mobileme的课程，以及事情如何最终以他们的方式。有趣的是听到所有的背景故事。

Apple University课程的课程之一是Mobileme崩溃的大部分是因为乔布斯不在乎它。当时，他与最新的iPhone充满了联系。他甚至没有介绍该产品，很多东西越过了他忽略的桌子。

像Twitter一样的社交帖子强制执行简洁，但我怀疑Gartenberg会同意，这并不是乔布斯根本不在乎Mobileme。正是他认为他不必足够关心才能将自己的注意力投入到它上。是的，Apple应该为某些在线基础知识（电子邮件，日历，联系人...）提供基于Web的功能，更重要的是，Apple应该为客户设备之间的数据提供无线Internet同步。而且，它应该只是在没有史蒂夫·乔布斯（Steve Jobs）密切关注Apple文件系统团队的当前状态的情况下进行硬盘“正常工作”的方式工作。但是事实证明，Mobileme并没有“仅仅工作”，乔布斯决定他需要给以激光注重的注意来重新开始并构建我们现在称为iCloud的东西（这真的非常好，非常可靠，我很久以前就超过了“ It It just just Onker”的阈值）。史蒂夫·乔布斯（Steve Jobs）在2011年WWDC的最终主题演讲主要集中在宣布iCloud上。

对于Siri和Apple Intelligence来说，谁在苹果公司内部担任该角色（公司内部高标准，良好的品味和影响力）？有人要说我们对此不太在乎，但是现在我们需要，并且会。

★

entry.title: “国民：Drexel微型计算项目”
entry.content:
来自Drexel的YouTube频道：

但是，众多认可的是，德雷克塞尔做出了非常大胆的决定，即使所有学生从苹果那里购买一台未经发布和未经测试的计算机。当然，这是Macintosh（1984年1月推出），这与以前的计算机不同。德雷克塞尔（Drexel）对Mac的承诺对苹果公司也有很大的好处，有助于使这个全新的平台合法化，这使Mac成为成功的产品，在40年后继续在教育中蓬勃发展。

这项名为Drexel Microcomputer项目的整个倡议是在2008年至2014年的Pennoni Honors学院院长David Jones拍摄的1小时纪录片中。这部电影于1985年在Drexel首映。

我很幸运，不仅认识戴夫·琼斯（Dave Jones）（他于2018年去世），而且还是让他成为几个电影批评课程的教授（一个在西方人，另一个在阿尔弗雷德·希区柯克（Alfred Hitchcock）的作品上）。我是计算机科学专业，不是电影专业的专业，但琼斯不在乎。他也很熟悉 - 我敢说，是我的专栏，在三角形，德雷克斯尔的学生报纸上。他带我去午餐，高三，鼓励我从事写作作为职业。他是一位很棒的老师：周到，善良，有见地，开放的思想和深刻的知识。

我在2011年看到了《全国民族》的放映，并与琼斯进行了小组讨论，讨论了这一点。这是一部不错的纪录片，他确实捕捉到了当时Drexel校园的感觉。这是一部80年代的电影。然后，我必须告诉他，他在1996年对我的建议很好。

★

entry.title: '40年前，德雷克塞尔制造了计算机和苹果 - 历史'
entry.content:
艾丽莎·法尔科内（Alissa Falcone）回顾了（我的母校）德雷克塞尔大学（Drexel University）40年前与苹果公司（Apple）达成的突破性协议，为所有学生提供了深折扣的Macintoshes，并将其整合到整个校园和课程中：

Drexel准备购买IBM计算机，并为其计算机中心配备了数十年的计算机中心 - 但费用为每单位超过1,000美元。另一方面，IBM的年轻竞争对手苹果愿意给予折扣，前提是大学同意对其最新，未发行的个人计算机进行秘密谈判和谨慎的表演。

布鲁斯·爱森斯坦（Bruce Eisenstein）博士，工程学院电气和计算机工程学教授布鲁斯·爱森斯坦（Bruce Eisenstein）是当时的电气和计算机工程系负责字体。这种新的Apple产品比早期的个人计算机更强大，更容易使用。据称，新手可以在30分钟内掌握它（无需记住并键入编码命令）。苹果同意以2,495美元出售给公众的车型的1,000美元价格。

“我回到了选拔委员会，我说，'听着，您必须忘记IBM。这台来自苹果公司的新计算机是您必须获得的。他们将以一千美元的速度向我们提供它，这是包容的。”第一个问题是“它与IBM计算机兼容吗？” Well, no. Was there software for it? No. Were there any programs for it, like a word processor? Not yet. So the committee justifiably kept saying, well, what's the name of this? What's it like? I couldn't tell them. I had to say you just gotta trust me on this. So they took a vote and unanimously voted to adopt the unknown computer that turned out to be the Macintosh,” Eisenstein recalled in Building Drexel: The University and Its城市，1891-2016 。

德雷克塞尔（Drexel）选择了未经测试的麦金托什（Macintosh），甚至知道苹果直到1984年1月才向公众宣布，直到三月份，计算机才准备好，几乎是在那个重要学年的一半。

我从来没有见过爱森斯坦的乐趣，但我肯定要感谢他的先知。到1991年我到达Drexel时，Mac在整个校园中都注入了。

★

entry.title: 最初的“库比蒂诺烂事” - 布伦特·施伦德（Brent Schlender）1997年的《财富》
entry.content:
在周五的抖动剧集中 -免费听- 本·汤普森（Ben Thompson）提醒我，上周我的标题参考文献（The Pline）提到了哈姆雷特（Hamlet ）著名的线条，以前曾经使用过一次。布伦特·施伦德（Brent Schlender）于1997年3月写了一篇《骗子》（Crackerjack），这是“库比蒂诺（Cupertino）腐烂的东西”的标题略有不同的标题。

我应该非常清楚地表明，我并不是要暗示我与我的作品。我们俩只是从莎士比亚的同一个习语上复活了。就我而言，我正在写一项倡议，该计划在一个非常成功，功能齐全的苹果中出现了问题。另一方面，Schlender作品的时间表是苹果历史上最不稳定和功能失调的时期。当时的首席执行官吉尔·阿梅利奥（Gil Amelio）刚刚宣布了1996年12月的下一批收购。到6月，大多数董事会将被替换，阿米利奥（Amelio）被解雇，史蒂夫·乔布斯（Steve Jobs）将以“顾问”的身份返回，并在1997年底以“临时CEO”的身份返回。 Schlender到处都是真正发生的事情：

在加利福尼亚州库比蒂诺市的苹果总部，正在进行强力发挥，引起人们的质疑，谁确实经营着公司，这很可能会再次发挥作用。这个情节是如此厚，以至于进入了硅谷一些最强大的CEO的家中。美味的讽刺是，触发肥皂剧的原因是Amelio希望是他的Masterstroke：Apple的4亿美元收购下一步，以及与之捆绑的史蒂夫·乔布斯（Steve Jobs）的咨询服务。

Amelio的大事开始看起来更像是对Apple的下一个接管。没关系，下一个软件是一家精品店，收入的收入将远小于苹果的四舍五入错误。乔布斯是硅谷的Svengali，这次可能已经超过了自己：他不仅收集了1亿美元和150万股苹果股的股票，但他的指纹在Amelio的最新重组计划和产品策略中都没有，即使乔布斯没有工作角色甚至董事会席位。

对于Machiavellian的眼睛来说，尽管好莱坞的诱惑似乎是工作 - 最近他一直在监督玩具总动员和其他计算机动画电影的制造商皮克斯（Pixar）可能正在为自己接管苹果。如果有人怀疑他能做到，那么您要做的就是问他最好的朋友Oracle首席执行官Larry Ellison是硅谷最富有的人。他说：“史蒂夫是唯一可以拯救苹果的人。”

我们都知道今天这正是它的表现。但是在1997年3月，这一点都没有明显。到今年年底，苹果是否仍然可以作为一家独立公司存在，甚至还不清楚。只是Schlender的非凡报告和讲故事。

entry.title: GSM协会的新RCS Spec添加了E2EE；苹果和Google都支持它
entry.content:
杰西（Jess Weatherbed），报道了边缘：

由于新更新的RCS规格，iPhone和Android用户将能够在不久的将来交换端到端加密（E2EE）RCS消息。 GSM协会宣布，最新的RCS标准包括基于消息层安全性（MLS）协议的E2EE，首次可以在不同平台提供商之间进行可互操作的加密。 [...]

Apple发言人Shane Bauer说：“端到端的加密是Imessage自一开始以来就支持的强大隐私和安全技术，现在我们很高兴领导跨行业的努力，将端到端的加密带入GSMA发表的RCS通用概况。” “我们将在未来的软件更新中向iOS，iPados，macos和WatchOS添加对端到端加密的RCS消息的支持。” [...]

Google发言人埃德·费尔南德斯（Ed Fernandez）对The Verge说：“我们一直致力于提供安全的消息传递体验，而Google消息用户多年来一直在端到端加密（E2EE）RCS消息传递。” “我们很高兴能够从GSMA中获得此更新的规范，并尽快与移动生态系统一起实施和扩展此重要的用户保护到跨平台RCS消息传递。”

这不过是个好消息。但是，沿着Google的界限构架这是错误的，他们一直在那里等待Apple支持RCS的E2EE。他们一直在等待Apple支持RCS ，是的，Google还为RCS实施了自己的专有E2EE层。但是到目前为止，开放RCS规格中还没有E2EE规范。现在有。这就是为什么无法使用E2EE的不仅仅是Android↔︎ios RCS消息传递，而且甚至Android↔︎Android，除非两个设备都使用Google自己的消息应用程序。

我最近还注意到，Google消息和Apple消息现在在支持彼此的Tapbacks方面做得很好。而且这并没有采取任何措施真正改变绿色/蓝色消息动态。这两种事情都是正确的：RCS使跨平台的消息传递更好，而iMessage仍然比RCS优越。

我对Apple实施RCS加密最感兴趣的是它们将如何在聊天中进行视觉表明。蓝色气泡不会。蓝色的意思是“ iMessage”，而不是“加密” - 恰好是iMessage作为基于端到端加密的协议开始。没有一个未加密的iMessage之类的东西 - 它是协议的一部分，并且一直都是。但是，当新/更新的Android手机支持新的RCS加密规范而旧设备没有时会发生什么？加密聊天的锁图标？如果取决于我，iOS将放弃对未加密的RCS的支持 - iOS应将带有E2EE的RCS用于每个支持它的设备，并返回到所有不使用的设备的愚蠢的旧无粘结式SMS。

entry.title: Google I/O 2025（5月20日至21日）的建议演示
entry.content:
Jay Peters, last month for The Verge:

Google's next I/O developer conference will take place on May 20th and May 21st, the company announced today . The event will be “open to everyone online” and will include “livestreamed keynotes and sessions,” according to an FAQ . Like past years, there will also be an in-person component at the Shoreline Amphitheatre in Mountain View, California.

That's still two months off but I got interested in the dates for I/O this week. After we recorded Friday's Dithering (on which we talked about my “ Something Is Rotten in the State of Cupertino ” piece and, more so, the reaction to it, the resonance it seemed to strike), Ben Thompson and I were spitballing , and it popped into my head that Apple's “more personalized Siri” delay is a marketing gift to Google.

What I would do if I worked at Google is prepare a live demo of Google Gemini on a Pixel phone doing exactly what Apple showed in last year's announcement at WWDC , and then again in the Bella Ramsey TV commercial that Apple pulled from YouTube.这样的事情：

Presenter: This is a live demo, on my Pixel 9. I need to pick my mom up at the airport and she sent me an email with her flight information. [ Invokes Gemini on phone in hand... ] Gemini, when is my mom's flight landing?

Gemini: Your mom's flight is on time, and arriving at SFO at 11:30.

Presenter: I don't always remember to add things to my calendar, and so I love that Gemini can help me keep track of plans that I've made in casual conversation, like this lunch reservation my mom mentioned in a text. [ Invokes Gemini... ] What's our lunch plan?

Gemini: You're having lunch at Waterbar at 12:30.

Presenter: How long will it take us to get there from the airport?

Gemini presents a Google Maps driving directions popup window showing it will take 21 minutes.

Then do another live demo with the “What's the name of the guy I had a meeting with a couple of months ago at Cafe Grenel?” example from Apple's now-pulled Apple Intelligence commercial. The exact same demos, but real: live and on stage. These would be great demos even if Apple had never promised to deliver them. But given that Apple did promise them for this year, and has now delayed them until “the coming year”, they're devastating if Google can show them actually working on Apple's own original timeline.

Stick to what Gemini can actually do, on actual Pixel phones running the new beta software — which by some accounts already includes the delayed personalized features of Siri . The point should be showing Google AI technology, accessing personal data from Google cloud services, using Google devices, delivering on the promises made by Apple a year prior. But there's no need for Google's presenters to mention Apple or Siri, or even mention unnamed “competitors”. Everyone watching the I/O keynote will recognize those demo prompts and draw the competitive conclusions for themselves. Nothing comes across as confident like not even acknowledging, let alone naming, your competition. And nothing serves as proof like a live working demo.

★

entry.title: 全手Siri团队会议泄漏到彭博
entry.content:
Mark Gurman, reporting for Bloomberg today:

Apple Inc.'s top executive overseeing its Siri virtual assistant told staff that delays to key features have been ugly and embarrassing, and a decision to publicly promote the technology before it was ready made matters worse.

罗比·沃克（Robby Walker）在苹果公司担任高级主任，他在Siri部门的全方位会议上发表了鲜明的评论，称该团队面临糟糕的时期。 Walker also said that it's unclear when the enhancements will actually launch, according to people with knowledge of the matter, who asked not to be identified because the gathering was private.

Robby Walker is not Apple's “top executive overseeing its Siri virtual assistant”. Take your pick of whether that's SVP John Giannandrea or CEO Tim Cook, but Walker reports to Giannandrea. Gurman, of course, knows this better than I do; I suspect he knows Apple's entire org chart. But it makes Bloomberg's headline — “Apple's Siri Chief Calls AI Delays Ugly and Embarrassing, Promises Fixes” — misleading. Also somewhat misleading in that headline is that these comments from Walker were clearly not meant to leak. This is not a public apology, like the one Tim Cook wrote and signed in 2012 in the aftermath of the Apple Maps launch with iOS 6.

尽管如此，他还是称赞该团队开发了“令人印象深刻的”功能，并誓言向消费者提供行业领先的虚拟助手。

Those two words are the only direct quote in the first nine paragraphs of Bloomberg's report, which is kind of crazy, because the second half of Gurman's story is full of quotes. I suspect his editors did Gurman a disservice on this one. The quotes are juicy AF, but don't really start until the 10th paragraph. Like, for example, which Siri features does Walker think are “incredibly impressive”? No snark, I'd love to know. Is it Siri's sports knowledge ? The new product knowledge feature, that gives incomplete and/or incorrect instructions for how to toggle preferences in Settings? OK I guess that's some snark, but I sincerely and honestly would love to know which Siri features the senior director in charge of Siri considers “incredibly impressive”.

沃克在会议上告诉工作人员，延误特别“丑陋”，因为苹果已经公开展示了这些功能。他说：“这不是这些情况之一，我们可以在计划后向人们展示我们的计划。” “我们以前向人们展示。”

“To make matters worse,” Walker said, Apple's marketing communications department wanted to promote the enhancements.

Again, this meeting clearly was not intended to leak. (It's perhaps another knock against the Siri team, in addition to the quality of their output, that they leak internal meetings.) But that comes across as Walker blaming marketing.

沃克还对即使达到当前发布期望也提出了怀疑。沃克说，尽管苹果的目标是iOS 19，但这并不意味着我们当时运输了。”沃克说。他说，该公司在开发方面还有更多优先事项，需要进行权衡。

沃克说：“我们在苹果公司对其他项目还有其他承诺。” “我们希望遵守对这些人的承诺，并且我们了解到这些人现在可能比推迟的特征更加紧张。”他说，随着明年计划的产品的进展，定时决定将按照“逐案”做出。

他说：“客户并不只期望这些新功能，但他们也想要一个更全面的Siri。” “We're going to ship these features and more as soon as they are ready.”

The customers still haven't gotten their appetizers, but it's time to start the entrees, so the kitchen staff is working on those now. But don't worry, they hope to get the appetizers out alongside dessert. But it's OK because dessert might be late too.

As of Friday, Apple doesn't plan to immediately fire any top executives over the AI crisis, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

I'd be very curious to know just how many people could possibly be familiar with this particular matter. Because this particular matter comes down to what Tim Cook is thinking. I'm thinking it's about six people he might discuss this with. Wait, no, I just thought of a seventh. I'm going to say seven, tops . But maybe I'm wrong, and Tim Cook is the chatty sort, who openly talks with a large number of senior managers about whom he might fire.

沃克说，由于质量问题而延迟功能的决定，该公司发现该技术只能在80％到80％的时间内正常工作。他说，该小组“可以取得更大的进步来提高这些百分比，以便用户可以真正依靠一些东西。”

It's unclear exactly which features these are in reference to, but presumably they're not the “incredibly impressive” ones. Because something that “only works properly up to two-thirds” of the time only seems regular impressive to me, not incredibly impressive. Maybe it's the ones that work properly four out of five times that are incredible?

沃克将这项工作与试图游泳前往夏威夷的努力进行了比较。 “We swam hundreds of miles — we set a Guinness Book for World Records for swimming distance — but we still didn't swim to Hawaii,” he said. “And we were being jumped on, not for the amazing swimming that we did, but the fact that we didn't get to the destination.”

I'd say it's a little more like selling customers tickets for a cruise that includes a stop in Hawaii, then never actually getting to Hawaii, and hoping they didn't notice when the ship returns to port to disembark.

He showed examples during the meeting of the technology working: It was able to locate his driver's license number on command and find specific photos of a child.他还展示了该技术如何通过语音控制精确地操纵应用程序。它嵌入了电子邮件中，添加了收件人并进行了其他更改。

That's the biggest actual news in the report, and it's in paragraph 23.

沃克说，一些工作人员可能会对延误感到“宽慰”。 “If you were using these features in the build, you were probably wondering: Are these ready? How do I feel about shipping these to our customers? Is this the right choice?”

他补充说，一些员工“可能会感到尴尬”。

Again, I'll reiterate that this was a private meeting, not meant to leak. Maybe it's an inaccurate summary.我希望是。 But as reported by Gurman, this meeting reeks of you-all-deserve-participation-trophies-to-reward-your-hard-work-and-it's-OK-to-feel-embarrassed vibes. What's needed, quite obviously, is some “What is it supposed to do? / So why the fuck doesn't it do that? ” vibes.

entry.summary: Who decided these personalized Siri features should go in the WWDC keynote, with a promise they'd arrive in the coming year, when, at the time, they were in such an unfinished state they could not be demoed to the media even in a controlled environment? Three months later, who decided Apple should double down and advertise these features in a TV commercial, and promote them as a selling point of the iPhone 16 lineup?
entry.content:
在我在这个球拍中的二十年中，我从来没有对自己错过一个故事比我在周五宣布的宣布的苹果智能的“更个性化的Siri”功能（原定出现在现在到现在的WWDC之间）的愤怒，这将被推迟到“来年”。

我应该检查头。

这一宣布令人惊讶，当然使我感到惊讶，但这从一开始就到了。我本来应该指出去年从WWDC开始的危险信号，我很尴尬，很抱歉，我从一开始就没有看到我应该很清楚的东西。

How I missed this is twofold. First, I'd been lulled into complacency by Apple's track record of consistently shipping pre-announced products and features. Their record in that regard wasn't perfect, but the exceptions tended to be around the edges. (Nobody was particularly clamoring for Apple to make a multi-device inductive charging mat, so it never generated too much controversy when AirPower turned out to be a complete bust .) Second, I was foolishly distracted by the “Apple Intelligence” brand umbrella. It's a fine idea for Apple to brand its AI features under an umbrella term like that, similar to how a bunch of disparate features that allow different Apple devices to interoperate are under the “ Continuity ” umbrella. But there's no such thing, technically speaking, as “Continuity”. It's not like there's an Xcode project inside Apple named Continuity.xcodeproj, and all the code that supports everything from AirDrop to Sidecar to iPhone Mirroring to clipboard sharing is all implemented in the same framework of code. It's a marketing term, but a useful one — it helps Apple explain the features, and helps users understand them.

The same goes for “Apple Intelligence”. It doesn't exist as a single thing or project. It's a marketing term for a collection of features, apps, and services. Putting it all under a single obvious, easily remembered — and easily promoted — name makes it easier for users to understand that Apple is launching a new initiative. It also makes it easier for Apple to just say “ These are the devices that qualify for all of these features, and other devices — older ones, less expensive ones — get none of them. ”

Let's say Apple were to quietly abandon the dumb Image Playground app next year. It just disappears from iOS 19 and MacOS 16. That would just be Apple eliminating a silly app that almost no one uses or should use. That wouldn't be a setback or rollback of “Apple Intelligence”. I would actually argue that axing Image Playground would improve Apple Intelligence; its mere existence greatly lowers the expectations for how good the whole thing is. 1

What I mean by that is that it was clear to me from the WWDC keynote onward that some of the features and aspects of Apple Intelligence were more ambitious than others. Some were downright trivial; others were proposing to redefine how we will do our jobs and interact with our most-used devices. That was clear. But yet somehow I didn't focus on it. Apple itself strongly hinted that the various features in Apple Intelligence wouldn't all ship at the same time. What they didn't spell out, but anyone could intuit, was that the more trivial features would ship first, and the more ambitious features later. That's where the red flags should have been obvious to me.

In broad strokes, there are four stages of “doneness” or “realness” to features announced by any company:

  1. Features that the company's own product representatives will demo, themselves, in front of the media. Smaller, more personal demonstrations are more credible than on-stage demos. But the stakes for demo fail are higher in an auditorium full of observers.

  2. Features that the company will allow members of the media (or other invited outside observers and experts) to try themselves, for a limited time, under the company's supervision and guidance. Vision Pro demos were like this at WWDC 2023. A bunch of us got to use pre-release hardware and in-progress software for 30 minutes. It wasn't like free range “Do whatever you want” — it was a guided tour. But we were the ones actually using the product. Apple allowed hands-on demos for a handful of media (not me) at Macworld Expo back in 2007 with prototype original iPhones — some of the “apps” were just screenshots, but most of the iPhone actually worked.

  3. Features that are released as beta software for developers, enthusiasts, and the media to use on their own devices, without limitation or supervision.

  4. Features that actually ship to regular users, and hardware that regular users can just go out and buy.

As of today — March 2025 — every feature in Apple Intelligence that has actually shipped was at level 1 back at WWDC. After the keynote, dozens of us in the press were invited to a series of small-group briefings where we got to watch Apple reps demo features like Writing Tools, Photos Clean Up, Genmoji, and more. We got to see predictive code completion in Xcode. What has shipped, as of today, they were able to show, in some functional state, in June.

For example, there was a demo involving a draft email message on an iPad, and the Apple rep used Writing Tools to make it “more friendly”. I was in a group of just four or five other members of the media, watching this. As usual, we were encouraged to interrupt with questions. Knowing that LLMs are non-deterministic, I asked whether, as the Apple rep was performing this same demo for each successive group of media members, the “more friendly” result was exactly the same each time. He laughed and said no — that while the results are very similar each time, and he hopes they continue to be (hence the laughing), that there were subtle differences sometimes between different runs of the same demo. As I recall, he even used Undo to go back to the original message text, invoked Writing Tools to make it “more friendly” again, and we could see that a few of the word choices were slightly different. That answered both my explicit question and my implicit one: Writing Tools generates non-deterministic results, and, more importantly, what we were watching really was a live demo.

We didn't get to try any of the Apple Intelligence features ourselves. There was no Apple Intelligence “hands on”. But we did see a bunch of features demoed, live, by Apple folks. In my above hierarchy of realness, they were all at level 1.

But we didn't see all aspects of Apple Intelligence demoed. None of the “more personalized Siri” features, the ones that Apple, in its own statement announcing their postponement , described as having “more awareness of your personal context, as well as the ability to take action for you within and across your apps”. Those features encompass three main things:

  • “Personal context” — Knowing details and information about you from a “semantic index”, built from the contents of your email, messages, files, contacts, and more. In theory, eventually, all the information on your device that you wish to share with Siri will be in this semantic index. If you can look it up on your device, Siri will be able to look it up on your device.
  • “Onscreen awareness” — Giving Siri awareness of whatever is displayed on your screen. Apple's own example usage : “If a friend texts you their new address, you can say 'Add this address to their contact card,' and Siri will take care of it.”

  • “In-app actions” — Giving Siri the ability, through the App Intents framework, to do things in and across apps that you can do, the old fashioned way (yourself) in and across apps. Again, here's Apple's own example usage:

    You can make a request like “Send the email I drafted to April and Lilly” and Siri knows which email you're referencing and which app it's in. And Siri can take actions across apps, so after you ask Siri to enhance a photo for you by saying “Make this photo pop,” you can ask Siri to drop it in a specific note in the Notes app — without lifting a finger.

There were no demonstrations of any of that. Those features were all at level 0 on my hierarchy. That level is called vaporware. They were features Apple said existed, which they claimed would be shipping in the next year, and which they portrayed , to great effect, in the signature “Siri, when is my mom's flight landing?” segment of the WWDC keynote itself, starting around the 1h:22m mark . Apple was either unwilling or unable to demonstrate those features in action back in June, even with Apple product marketing reps performing the demos from a prepared script using prepared devices.

This shouldn't have just raised a concern in my head. It should have set off blinding red flashing lights and deafening klaxon alarms.

Even the very engineers working on a project never know exactly how long something is going to take to complete. An outsider observing a scripted demo of incomplete software knows far less (than the engineers) just how much more work it needs. But you can make a rough judgment. And that's where my aforementioned hierarchy of realness comes into play. Even outsiders can judge how close a public beta (stage 3) feels to readiness. A feature or product that Apple will allow the press to play with, hands-on (stage 2) is further along than a feature or product that Apple is only willing to demonstrate themselves (stage 1).

But a feature or product that Apple is unwilling to demonstrate, at all, is unknowable. Is it mostly working, and close to, but not quite, demonstratable? Is it only kinda sorta working — partially functional, but far from being complete? Fully functional but prone to crashing — or in the case of AI, prone to hallucinations and falsehoods? Or is it complete fiction, just an idea at this point?

What Apple showed regarding the upcoming “personalized Siri” at WWDC was not a demo. It was a concept video. Concept videos are bullshit, and a sign of a company in disarray, if not crisis. The Apple that commissioned the futuristic “Knowledge Navigator” concept video in 1987 was the Apple that was on a course to near-bankruptcy a decade later. Modern Apple — the post-NeXT-reunification Apple of the last quarter century — does not publish concept videos. They only demonstrate actual working products and features.

Until WWDC last year, that is.

去年，我在WWDC上对“苹果智能”的心理框架深深地误导了：其中一些功能比其他功能更远，而苹果公司首先向我们展示了这些功能，它们肯定是明年一年中首次发货的功能。 The other features must be coming to demonstratable status soon. But the mental framework I should have used was more like this: Some of these features are merely table stakes for generative AI in 2024, but others are ambitious, groundbreaking, and, given their access to personal data, potentially dangerous. Apple is only showing us the table-stakes features, and isn't demonstrating any of the ambitious, groundbreaking, risky features.

情况变得更糟。 Come September, Apple held its annual big event at Apple Park to unveil the iPhone 16 lineup. Apple Intelligence features were highlighted in the announcement. Members of the media from around the world were gathered. That was a new opportunity, three months after WWDC, for Apple to demonstrate — or even better, offer hands-on access to the press to try themselves — the new personalized Siri features. They did not. No demos, at all. But they did promote them, once again, in the event keynote. 2

But yet while Apple still wouldn't demonstrate these features in person, they did commission and broadcast a TV commercial showing these purported features in action, presenting them as a reason to purchase a new iPhone — a commercial they pulled, without comment, from YouTube this week .

Last week's announcement — “It's going to take us longer than we thought to deliver on these features and we anticipate rolling them out in the coming year” — was, if you think about it, another opportunity to demonstrate the current state of these features.他们不仅会向媒体发表声明，还可以邀请媒体的精选成员到苹果公园，或者在纽约的苹果办公室，甚至通过WebEx电话会议远程访问，并在实际设备上展示了这些功能现场的现状。那没有发生。 If these features exist in any sort of working state at all, no one outside Apple has vouched for their existence, let alone for their quality.

Duke Nukem Intelligence

Why did Apple show these personalized Siri features at WWDC last year, and promise their arrival during the first year of Apple Intelligence? Why, for that matter, do they now claim to “anticipate rolling them out in the coming year” if they still currently do not exist in demonstratable form? (If they do exist today in demonstratable form, they should, you know, demonstrate them .)

I'm not trying to be obtuse here. It's obvious why some executives at Apple might have hoped they could promote features like these at WWDC last year. Generative AI is the biggest thing to happen in the computer industry since previous breakthroughs this century like mobile (starting with the iPhone, followed by Android), social media (Meta), and cloud computing (Microsoft, Google, and Amazon). Nobody knows where it's going but wherever it's heading, it's going to be big, important, and perhaps profitable. Wall Street certainly noticed. And prior to WWDC last year, Apple wasn't in the game. They needed to pitch their AI story. And a story that involved nothing but table-stakes AI features isn't nearly as compelling a story as one that involves innovative, breakthrough, ambitious personal features.

But while there's an obvious appeal to Apple pitching the most compelling, most ambitious AI story possible, the only thing that was essential was telling a story that was true.如果事实是苹果在来年与其他业务相比，苹果只有准备发货的功能，那就是他们需要讲的故事。 Put as good a spin on it as possible, but them's the breaks when you're late to the game.

The fiasco here is not that Apple is late on AI. It's also not that they had to announce an embarrassing delay on promised features last week. Those are problems, not fiascos, and problems happen. They're inevitable. Leaders prove their mettle and create their legacies not by how they deal with successes but by how they deal with — how they acknowledge, understand, adapt, and solve — problems. The fiasco is that Apple pitched a story that wasn't true, one that some people within the company surely understood wasn't true, and they set a course based on that.

The Apple of the Jobs exile years — the Sculley / Spindler / Amelio Apple of 1987–1997 — promoted all sorts of amazing concepts that were no more real than the dinosaurs of Jurassic Park , and promised all sorts of hardware and (especially) software that never saw the light of day. Promoting what you hope to be able to someday ship is way easier and more exciting than promoting what you know is actually ready to ship. However close to financial bankruptcy Apple was when Steve Jobs returned as CEO after the NeXT reunification, the company was already completely bankrupt of credibility. Apple today is the most profitable and financially successful company in the history of the world. Everyone notices such success, and the corresponding accumulation of great wealth. Less noticed, but to my mind the more impressive achievement, is that over the last three decades, the company also accumulated an abundant reserve of credibility. When Apple showed a feature, you could bank on that feature being real. When they said something was set to ship in the coming year, it would ship in the coming year. In the worst case, maybe that “year” would have to be stretched to 13 or 14 months. You can stretch the truth and maintain credibility, but you can't maintain credibility with bullshit. And the “more personalized Siri” features, it turns out, were bullshit.

Keynote by keynote, product by product, feature by feature, year after year after year, Apple went from a company that you couldn't believe would even remain solvent, to, by far, the most credible company in tech. Apple remains at no risk of financial bankruptcy (and in fact remains the most profitable company in the world). But their credibility is now damaged. Careers will end before Apple might ever return to the level of “if they say it, you can believe it” credibility the company had earned at the start of June 2024.

Damaged is arguably too passive. It was squandered . This didn't happen to Apple. Decision makers within the company did it.

Who decided these features should go in the WWDC keynote, with a promise they'd arrive in the coming year, when, at the time, they were in such an unfinished state they could not be demoed to the media even in a controlled environment? Three months later, who decided Apple should double down and advertise these features in a TV commercial, and promote them as a selling point of the iPhone 16 lineup — not just any products, but the very crown jewels of the company and the envy of the entire industry — when those features still remained in such an unfinished or perhaps even downright non-functional state that they still could not be demoed to the press? Not just couldn't be shipped as beta software.不仅可以在动手体验中被媒体成员使用，而且甚至无法证明Apple员工在Apple控制的设备上在Apple控制的环境中工作吗？但是，他们在iPhone 16的广告中做广告，当发现他们不会发货时，在最好的情况下，直到iPhone 17阵容揭幕之后的几个月？

当广告的整个活动出现时，我和许多其他观察家都因苹果情报中的任何功能尚未发货而分心。苹果宣传所有尚未发货的功能，这是非常不寻常的，可以说是不寻常的。但是其中一个广告完全不像其他广告。其他广告具有接近运输的Apple Intelligence功能。我们知道今天他们已经接近运输，因为它们已经在9月的iOS 18.1 BETA中，要么很快就会出现在iOS 18.2和18.3的开发人员Beta中。现在，今天，他们实际上已经发货了，并且掌握在iPhone 16用户手中。但是“ Siri，我几个月前在咖啡馆格林内尔与我开会的那个家伙的名字是什么？”广告完全是基于苹果仍然从未证明的功能。

谁说“当然，让我们保证这一点”，然后“当然，让我们做广告”？ And who said “ Are you crazy, this isn't ready, this doesn't work, we can't promote this now? ” And most important, who made the call which side to listen to?据推测，那个人是蒂姆·库克（Tim Cook）。

即使苹果在WWDC主题演讲中苹果过度宣传（如果不是彻底撒谎），新闻媒体的WWDC的最初收获也被错误地集中在与Openai的合作伙伴关系上。主题演讲中传统的智慧是苹果刚刚宣布了“苹果智能”的内容，但它是由chatgpt驱动的，而实际上，苹果的故事是，苹果的故事是，他们（苹果）建立了一个称为Apple Intellighent的整个系统，完全由Apple自己的AI技术供电，并且它不仅限于新的私人范围，但他们不仅可以掌握私人范围的执行，但他们不仅限于私人云的执行，但他们却无限制地执行了私人构造，但他们却无所不在。基于苹果硅芯片的硬件。最重要的是，作为顶部众所周知的樱桃，苹果还与Chatgpt添加了一个可选的集成层。

因此，是的，鉴于新闻媒体为苹果自己的实际宣布成就赢得了Openai的荣誉，如果他们不宣布“更个性化的Siri”功能，苹果肯定会得到更少的信誉。 It's easy to imagine someone in the executive ranks arguing “ We need to show something that only Apple can do. ” But it turns out they announced something Apple couldn't do.现在，他们看上去是如此的深度，因此在他们的头顶上，不仅在AI中最先进的几年后，他们甚至都不知道自己可以发货或何时发货。他们九个月前的标题功能不仅没有发货，而且还没有被证明，我现在认为这意味着他们无法证明它们，因为它们不起作用。

蒂姆·库克（Tim Cook）应该已经举行了这样的会议，以解决和纠正这一Siri和Apple Intelligence崩溃。如果这样的会议尚未发生或没有很快发生，那么我担心，这就是她写的。旅程结束了。当平庸，借口和废话扎根时，他们接管了。卓越，问责制和诚信的文化不能遵守任何这些事物的接受，并且会在接受这三个事物的情况下迅速崩溃。

Filipe Espósito, reporting last week for 9to5Mac:

As reported by Brazilian newspaper Valor Econômico (via O Globo ), a federal judge in Brazil ruled on Wednesday that Apple will have to open up the iOS ecosystem to third-party apps in Brazil just like the company did in the EU. The judge considers that the “limitations” imposed by the company on developers could jeopardize the entry of new competitors in the segment. [...]

The judge states that, despite Apple's claims, the company “has already complied with similar obligations in other countries, without demonstrating a significant impact or irreparable damage to its business model.”

Presumably Apple will just roll out in Brazil the same compliance rules, policies, and APIs that they started offering last year in the EU. But will Brazilian users get access to EU third-party app marketplaces, and vice-versa? Or will Apple try to segregate these app marketplaces region-by-region, such that Brazilian users will only get access to Brazilian third-party app marketplaces, and EU users will remain limited only to EU third-party app marketplaces?

I asked Riley Testut, the founder of AltStore PAL , if he knew the answers to those questions. His answer, via iMessage:

We haven't heard anything from Apple (unsurprisingly), but I think it'll be somewhere in the middle. It's likely Apple will add some requirements for existing marketplaces to launch in Brazil like they did with EU (eg requiring us to have a subsidiary in Brazil) so we'll all need to get approval again. But assuming marketplaces meet all requirements, I think users in both places will eventually be able use eg AltStore PAL and Epic Games Store.

“In the middle” sounds about right from Apple's perspective too. They're not going to make this as easy as possible, but I don't expect them to make it obstinately spiteful either.

entry.summary: You either have taste or you don't, and most people don't, at least for judging something new and unfamiliar.
entry.content:
Ben Lovejoy, writing at 9to5Mac :

Our editor-in-chief Chance Miller wryly commented that a radical new look would serve as a great way to distract from the ever-slowing progress on the new Siri. But in truth, I think many more Apple users will be wowed by a new look than would ever care about Siri.

If that's the way it works out — with a new visual look drawing attention from lackluster progress on the AI front — surely the timing will be coincidental, but some accidents are happy accidents, as Bob Ross used to say.

Sure, the new look introduced with iOS 7 was a massively controversial one, and many thought that then Apple design chief Jony Ive should never have been allowed anywhere near the software side of the business. But love it or hate it, you certainly couldn't ignore it.

The same will be true of a new 3D look, which might even include some (much more modern) skeuomorphic elements. Probably as many will hate it as love it when it's first introduced, as that seems to be true of any significant change made by the company, but it will likely make more of a bang than any improvement to Siri the company may introduce, then or later.

There should be no question that all of what Lovejoy is saying here is true. If Apple launches an all-new systemwide UI theme for iOS 19, something even half as radical a change as iOS 7's theme was, it will be the only thing most users notice or opine about. Humans are fundamentally visual creatures and we notice visual changes. And, most humans are resistant to change. A lot of people simply dislike change, even changes for the better. (Honestly, I think that's what the iOS 18 Photos complaints are about. Complaints about change itself.)

Part of what makes Apple Apple is that the company is (or at least should be) led by people who both have great taste and trust their own instincts. No one's taste is perfect. Even Steve Jobs pushed through a few clunkers . But if you have great taste and confidence, you'll do what your gut says is right.

When a company only pushes out changes that avoid controversy, it leads to paralysis. Then stagnation. Earlier today, Cabel Sasser wrote :

One of my strongest early developer memories was being in the “UI Feedback Forum” at WWDC after they introduced Aqua. Think of a live Q&A, but developers giving notes to a team of Apple engineers.

To these veteran Mac coders, the reaction to Aqua was universally negative. People were actively very angry.这是浪费！ It's ugly!令人困惑！你怎么能。 It went on and on, and I was surprised because Aqua looked cool and fun to me.

After that WWDC, they never did another Feedback Forum.

是的。 What a lot of Mac users wanted was a Mac OS X that looked like Mac OS 9. 1 The Aqua look and feel was definitely polarizing. And Apple dialed back its most exuberant details with each subsequent Mac OS X update — less transparency, subtler pinstripes (pinstripes!), etc. But iOS 7 was equally polarizing, and its excesses also got dialed back (or perhaps better, said, dialed back up) with each successive iOS release — a little more depth, some subtle hints of texture.

Either Apple is never going to ship an altogether new UI theme, or they'll ship one and a large number of people will declare it utter garbage and proof that Apple has completely lost its way. Maybe it will be garbage and proof that Apple has lost its way! Or, maybe it will actually prove to be a great new look that starts a decade-long industry-wide trend that all other companies will soon follow — which is what happened with Aqua's 3D “lickability”, and happened again with iOS 7's austere flattening. But either way, you won't be able to judge it by asking for a show of hands from the general population when it's unveiled . You either have taste or you don't, and most people don't, at least when judging something new and unfamiliar.

  1. Which is actually what 1999's Mac OS X Server 1.0 looked like . It really was the best-looking version of the classic Platinum UI theme Apple ever released. ↩︎

We speak of the universe like we speak of the planet , which is lowercase.) It's almost disrespectful to lowercase it, and the Internet is one of the great achievements in the history of mankind.

entry.title: 西蒙·威利森（Simon Willison）关于个性化Siri的隐私/安全风险，相对于及时注射
entry.content:
西蒙·威利森（Simon Willison）：

These new Apple Intelligence features involve Siri responding to requests to access information in applications and then performing actions on the user's behalf.

This is the worst possible combination for prompt injection attacks! Any time an LLM-based system has access to private data, tools it can call and exposure to potentially malicious instructions (like emails and text messages from untrusted strangers) there's a significant risk that an attacker might subvert those tools and use them to damage or exfiltrate a user's data.

I published this piece about the risk of prompt injection to personal digital assistants back in November 2023, and nothing has changed since then to make me think this is any less of an open problem.

迅速注射似乎是LLM提供商可以减轻但无法完全解决的问题。 They can tighten the lid, but they can't completely seal it. But with your private information, the lid needs to be provably sealed — an airtight seal, not a “ well, don't turn it upside down or shake it ” seal.因此，看一种个性化的Siri Imbroglio的一种悲观方法是，Apple无法负担得起这一错误，但是LLMS迅速注射的敏感性的性质可能意味着不可能做到正确。如果可能的话，将需要开创性的成就。 It's not enough for Apple to “catch up”. They have to solve a vexing problem — as yet unsolved by OpenAI, Google, or any other leading AI lab — to deliver what they've already promised.

So Apple had promised for this year — and oft promoted — an entire set of features that they not only have now acknowledged will not ship this year, but which they might, in fact, never be able to ship.让我想知道苹果内部有多少人在一年前表达了这​​些问题，以及为什么他们失去了去年6月开始承诺这些功能并在9月份进行广告宣传的辩论。

entry.summary: 这一公告令人失望，但并不奇怪。 If it's Apple's general policy not to ship a product before it's ready, that applies tenfold for a product involving LLM access to deeply private on-device information.
entry.content:
这是我今天早上从苹果发言人杰奎琳·罗伊（Jacqueline Roy）逐字了解的声明：

“Siri helps our users find what they need and get things done quickly, and in just the past six months, we've made Siri more conversational, introduced new features like type to Siri and product knowledge, and added an integration with ChatGPT. We've also been working on a more personalized Siri, giving it more awareness of your personal context, as well as the ability to take action for you within and across your apps. It's going to take us longer than we thought to deliver on these features and we anticipate rolling them out in the coming year.”

This is a Friday sort of wah-waaah sad-trombone news drop, but it's good that Apple is getting on top of it, and setting expectations accurately.

读这条线之间的读物以及根据我在库比蒂诺 - 埃斯（Cupertino-Ese）中的博士学位流利度，苹果在这里所说的是，这些“更个性化的Siri”功能从今年的OS周期到明年：iOS 19和MacOS 16。 Those years effectively start at WWDC.从苹果的角度来看，问题是他们没有谈论未来的产品。 They haven't officially acknowledged there is going to be an iOS 19 or MacOS 16. They haven't even yet announced that there's going to be a WWDC 2025. But they do want to set expectations accurately, especially for a feature as high profile — from Apple's own marketing push — as Apple Intelligence.所以我们在这里。

It was already pretty obvious these features weren't coming in iOS 18.4/MacOS 15.4, because they're not in the developer betas that are already out.如果这些功能在iOS 18.5/macOS 15.5甚至iOS 18.6/macOS 15.6中出现，那么苹果就不会觉得有必要发表“这需要我们比我们想象的更长的……”声明。 Delivering the “more personalized Siri” in iOS 18.5 or even 18.6 would have been delivering them on the originally announced schedule — the “coming year” that began with WWDC 2024. That would have been the tail end of that “year”, but within it. But Apple, being limited to the self-imposed opaque verbiage of Cupertino-ese, isn't going to spell that out. But trust me, you can bank on it: what they're announcing today is that these features are coming in iOS 19/MacOS 16.

Siri在今年的OS周期（iOS/iPados 18 + MacOS 15红杉）中的苹果智能伞下的几种有用但迭代的方法有所改善，但是去年6月在WWDC上展出的大型“个性化的Siri”是Siri相关的Apple Intelligence，这些东西是人们，人们对此很兴奋，最令人兴奋。 This is the “ App Intents ” stuff — the features requiring Siri to have access to and, effectively, understanding of your personal information, in your apps, stored privately on your devices. These are the most helpful-sounding, most practical, most futuristic features of Apple Intelligence. And they're the sort of features Apple is almost uniquely positioned to offer, alongside only Google, as the provider of a mobile platform and device ecosystem.

From Apple's own announcement , after the WWDC keynote:

Siri will be able to deliver intelligence that's tailored to the user and their on-device information. For example, a user can say, “Play that podcast that Jamie recommended,” and Siri will locate and play the episode, without the user having to remember whether it was mentioned in a text or an email. Or they could ask, “When is Mom's flight landing?” Siri将找到飞行的详细信息，并通过实时飞行跟踪交叉引用，以提供到达时间。

“妈妈什么时候登陆？” is easily understood, by we humans, and a really good example of the sort of Siri interaction that would be obviously useful. But you can also pretty easily see how complex it is on Apple's side. Siri has long been able to do the “Mom” thing. Your spouse, your kids — you've long able to tell Siri to call or text those people by nickname like that.但是，从您的电子邮件中获取妈妈的飞行信息（我认为这是WWDC主题演示中此演示的前提 - 飞行信息被存储在邮件中或短信中，然后知道如何检查该航班的当前飞行状态信息，这远远超出了当前Siri的Ken。 Getting the information requires access to your most personal information — your own email and messages. Getting the correct information from your messages requires the common sense of understanding that you're obviously asking about some sort of current trip your mom is taking, not, say, an email she sent you about a flight back in 2019, or one from 2022, or even one from December last year. The Siri we currently know lacks that sort of common sense . And then lastly, after getting the correct flight from your email, performing this task requires Siri to have the agency to go look up the current status of that particular flight — and get it right every time it provides an answer.

If Siri answers, “Your mom's flight is arriving at 4:30 this afternoon, and it's currently showing an on-time arrival,” you really want that information to be correct if you've promised to pick her up at the airport.如果您开车去机场，您会很生气，事实证明她直到7:30才真正着陆。 And you'll be in real trouble if she's landing at 1:30 and you show up three hours later, having banked on Siri's answer being accurate.

It's very unusual, to say the least, for Apple to announce a product delay. 1 The white iPhone 4 was supposed to debut alongside the black one in June 2010, but, bizarrely, was delayed several times ( which I had fun with more than once ) and wound up not shipping until the end of April the next year , 10 months late. The original AirPods were announced alongside the iPhones 7 in September 2016, and were supposed to ship in October.他们最终被推迟到12月。 Apple's statement in October 2016, regarding the AirPods being delayed, as given to Matthew Panzarino at TechCrunch :

“The early response to AirPods has been incredible. We don't believe in shipping a product before it's ready, and we need a little more time before AirPods are ready for our customers.”

这就是为什么Apple掌握了几乎宗教政策，即在准备好之前没有宣布产品。当他们确实做出例外时（如上所述，如上所述（如下），他们经常后悔。 You can't break a promise you never made, and you can't miss a ship date you never announced. Even with talented teams and realistic managers, there's often a long span between how long you expect a project to take and how long it actually winds up taking. Engineering schedules often slip even with predictable technologies, and the non-deterministic nature of LLMs makes their future inherently unpredictable.

苹果情报的大部分感觉就像苹果公司已经将其推迟了一年，比公司通常的烘焙水平提前了一年。我全年都认为，如果整个行业与华尔街一起 - 没有进入生成型/LLM躁狂症，那么直到今年的WWDC而不是去年才宣布“苹果情报”。今天的宣布令人失望，但对我来说毫不奇怪。通过应用程序意图与个人数据的Siri集成从未感觉像在今年的OS周期中为真实客户使用做好准备的事情。而且，如果苹果公司的一般政策在准备好之前不运送产品，则适用于涉及LLM访问深度私人式智障信息的产品十倍。要迟到，但准备就绪，比运送一些未完成或不可靠的东西要命中应许的截止日期。凭借下一代Siri之类的东西，我想说这是至关重要的。 Apple can take the bad publicity today's announcement is engendering; they cannot afford to squander the trust of their users.

  1. 当然，现代时代的苹果产品延迟的祖父是Airpower- Apple在2017年9月与iPhone X和iPhone 8一起预言的多设备（iPhone，Apple Watch，AirPods）充电设备。 It wound up never shipping, but the plug wasn't officially pulled (so to speak) until 29 March 2019 , an absurd 18 months after it was announced. ↩︎

entry.summary: From the perspective of a company the size of Disney, it would cost veritable pennies to keep FiveThirtyEight's website around forever.多么耻辱。
entry.content:
Oliver Darcy, reporting at Status (paywalled, alas), on the sudden demise of FiveThirtyEight :

On Wednesday morning, shortly after sending an all-staff memo announcing layoffs at ABC News, network president Almin Karamehmedovic joined a virtual meeting with the FiveThirtyEight team. ABC新闻拥有的政治分析网站上的15名员工通过华尔街日报的报告了解到了前一天晚上，他们被放开了。 Now, they were hearing it from Karamehmedovic himself.

但是，像其他经理在当天在ABC新闻上进行大规模裁员的其他经理人一样，对此几乎没有话要说。 I'm told he appeared to be reading from a script as he delivered the devastating news.他没有提供有关为什么迪士尼拥有的网络决定关闭FiveThirtyeight的原因，该网络与Data Whiz和当时的编辑Nate Silver一起收购。 He took no questions. He simply thanked the employees for their work, told them a human resources staffer would follow up, and ended the meeting. The entire affair, I'm told, lasted about 15 minutes.不久之后，员工可以访问ABC新闻的系统关闭，而FiveThirtyeight网站也被脱机。就这样，它结束了。

业务是业务，裁员和关闭绝不是创伤。 But there's a right way to do things and a wrong way.错误的方法之一是让工作人员发现自己都通过阅读《华尔街日报》而被解雇。 This guy Karamehmedovic sounds like a real Grade-A dickhead.

与这些公司关闭网站时毫不客气地插入插件的公司怎么办？ Why not keep the FiveThirtyEight site up and running — at least for a while, if not in perpetuity? It costs practically nothing to run a server for a static/archived website.我不明白。 It betrays a profound level of disrespect for the work that the site hosted. It's ABC's business if they want to close FiveThirtyEight as an ongoing concern, but the years of work deserves to remain online, both out of respect for the people who made it and for the audience that might still want to refer to it.迪士尼没有像Touchstone Pictures这样关闭的子公司工作室燃烧电影。

旧的印刷世界与在线出版的新世界之间存在着巨大的鸿沟。 The difference is profound, but largely overlooked, because it's human nature to just adapt to the nature of different forms of media and quickly accept current media forms as “normal”. With print, issues were largely ephemeral to the audience. You'd get a newspaper every day, and magazines every week or month, and you'd throw them out after you'd finished reading them. If you wanted to look back at what the paper had published about something a year, a month, or even just a few days ago, you were out of luck, in terms of being able to just look it up on the spot.图书馆员从事Yeoman的工作，将报纸和杂志归为缩微胶卷，所以什么都没有消失或遗忘，但是访问缩微胶卷档案是一种巨大的麻烦。 You pretty much had to know the dates of the issues you wanted to see, and you had to do the “searching” with your eyeballs, page by page.今天，任何人都可以立即访问一周，一个月，年甚至数十年的故事的能力是网络出版物的令人叹为观止的优势。在过去的15年左右的时间里，我们有能力从我们所有人的口袋里都携带的小机器来做到这一点。这是真的很棒。

但是关闭Web出版物时的标准行为就是仅拉插头。当整个公司陷入困境时，那是一回事。 But when there's a parent company, especially a thriving one, there's no justification for pulling the plug other than spiteful disregard for the work. From the perspective of a company the size of Disney, it would cost veritable pennies to keep FiveThirtyEight's website around forever.多么耻辱。

entry.content:
Nora Deligter, writing for Screen Slate in June 2023, “ Elegy for the Screenshot ”:

About five years ago, Catherine Pearson started taking screenshots of every bouquet featured on The Nanny (1993–1999), the six-season CBS sitcom that was then streaming on Netflix. She was just becoming a florist, and she found the arrangements — ornate, colorful, and distinctly tropical — inspirational. She now keeps them in a folder on her desktop, alongside screenshots of flower arrangements featured on Poirot (1989–2013), the British detective drama. A few months ago, however, Pearson suddenly found that when her fingers danced instinctively toward Command-Shift-3, she was greeted by a black box where her flowers used to be, a censored version of what she had meant to capture.

It was around this time when streaming platforms like Netflix, HBO Max, Amazon Prime, and the Criterion Channel imposed a quiet embargo on the screenshot. At first, there were workarounds: users could continue to screenshot by using the browser Brave or by downloading extensions or third-party tools like Fireshot. But gradually, the digital-rights-management tech adapted and became more sophisticated. Today, it is nearly impossible to take a screenshot from the most popular streaming services, at least not on a Macintosh computer. [...]

For PC users, this story takes a different, and happier, turn. With the use of Snipping Tool — a utility exclusive to Microsoft Windows, users are free to screen grab content from all streaming platforms. This seems like a pointed oversight, a choice on the part of streamers to exclude Mac users (though they make up a tiny fraction of the market) because of their assumed cultural class. This assumption isn't unreasonable. Out of everyone interviewed for this article, only one of them was a PC user.

Deligter's essay has been sitting in my long (and ever-growing) list of things to link to ever since she published it back in 2023. I referenced it in my post earlier today re: Matthew Green's entreaty to Apple to add “disappearing messages” to iMessage, and re-reading it made me annoyed enough to finally write about it.

I'm not entirely sure what the technical answer to this is, but on MacOS, it seemingly involves the GPU and video decoding hardware. These DRM blackouts happen at such a low level that no high-level software — any sort of utility you might install — can route around them. I think Windows still offers easy screenshotting of frames from DRM video not because the streaming services somehow don't care about what Windows users do (which, when you think about it, would be a weird thing not to care about, given Windows's market share), but because Windows uses a less sophisticated imaging pipeline. Or perhaps rather than less sophisticated , it's more accurate to say less integrated . These DRM blackouts on Apple devices (you can't capture screenshots from DRM video on iPhones or iPads either) are enabled through the deep integration between the OS and the hardware, thus enabling the blackouts to be imposed at the hardware level. And I don't think the streaming services opt into this screenshot prohibition other than by “protecting” their video with DRM in the first place. If a video is DRM-protected, you can't screenshot it; if it's not, you can.

On the Mac, it used to be the case that DRM video was blacked-out from screen capture in Safari, but not in Chrome (or the dozens of various Chromium-derived browsers). But at some point a few years back, you stopped being able to capture screenshots from DRM videos in Chrome, too — by default . But in Chrome's Settings page, under System, if you disable “Use graphics acceleration when available” and relaunch Chrome, boom, you can screenshot everything in a Chrome window, including DRM video. You can go to the magic URL chrome://gpu/ before and after toggling this setting to see a full report on the differences — as you'd expect, it turns off all hardware acceleration for video encoding/decoding, compositing, and more. You wouldn't want to browse like this all the time (certainly not on battery power), but it's a great trick to know for capturing stills from videos.

What I don't understand is why Apple bothered supporting this in the first place for hardware-accelerated video (which is all video on iOS platforms — there is no workaround like using Chrome with hardware acceleration disabled on iPhone or iPad). No one is going to create bootleg copies of DRM-protected video one screenshotted still frame at a time — and even if they tried, they'd be capturing only the images, not the sound. And it's not like this “feature” in MacOS and iOS has put an end to bootlegging DRM-protected video content. This “feature” accomplishes nothing of value for anyone, including the streaming services, but imposes a massive (and for most people, confusing and frustrating) hindrance on honest people simply trying to easily capture high-quality (as opposed to, say, using their damn phone to take a photograph of their reflective laptop display) screenshots of the shows and movies they're watching.
